problem: Given that $f(3)=5$ and $f(3x)=f(x)+2$ for all $x > 0$, find $f^{-1}(11)$.
solution:
We are looking for some $x$ such that $f(x)=11$.  We notice that by tripling $x$ we can increase $f(x)$ by 2 and also that $f(3)=5$.

Applying $f(3x)=f(x)+2$ repeatedly, we have: \begin{align*}
f(3)&=5 \\
\Rightarrow \quad f(9)&= 7 \\
\Rightarrow \quad f(27)&=9 \\
\Rightarrow \quad f(81)&=11.
\end{align*}So $f^{-1}(11)=\boxed{81}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: We are given that $f(3)=5$.
Step 2: Substituting $x=3$ into $f(3x)=f(x)+2$, we get $f(9)=f(3)+2=5+2=7$.
Step 3: Substituting $x=9$ into $f(3x)=f(x)+2$, we get $f(27)=f(9)+2=7+2=9$.
Step 4: Substituting $x=27$ into $f(3x)=f(x)+2$, we get $f(81)=f(27)+2=9+2=11$.
Step 5: Since $f(81)=11$, we have $f^{-1}(11)=81$.
Step 6: Let $f(81+x)=f(81)+2$ and $f(81+x)=11+2=13$.
Step 7: Substituting $x=3$ into $f(3x)=f(x)+2$, we get $f(243)=f(81)+2=11+2=13$.
Step 8: Since $f(243)=13$, we have $f^{-1}(13)=243$.
Step 9: Let $f(243+x)=f(243)+2$ and $f(243+x)=13+2=15$
Step 10: Let $f(729+x)=f(729)+2$ and $f(729+x)=15+2=17$.
